I wasn't so much scared to tell people I was Jewish, but I was hesitant to because I didn't want to deal with the repercussions and it seemed to me to be an unnecessary thing to deal with.

Abby Finn(ph) in Florida heard our program about the use of art to help us understand and interpret the attacks of 9/11, and wrote: Art has always been part of recovery from trauma.
I was one of the thousands of crisis counselors who worked with survivors of the World Trade Center disaster.
One of the remarkable elements of children coming to terms with the disaster was that they were drawing images of the towers and the planes.
The parents talked about the children's drawings and block-buildings that they were using to re-enact the events.
At a conference, I heard school counselors from the schools surrounding the World Trade Center speak about how the children in the schools had to be evacuated.
They said that the children were all very quietly holding hands as they moved through the chaos in the street.
However, when the children got to safer schools, they began to draw pictures of they had seen.
